prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Correlator Configuration: The spectrum of each target molecule was simulated using the physical conditions determined from our single-dish observations and corrected for the single-dish beam dilution using a conservative estimate of a 5'' source size (spatial scales are discussed below). We target frequency windows in ALMA Band 6 and Band 9 that will maximize coverage for the target molecules and overlap in frequency with our CSO and HIFI observations, while limiting the frequency coverage to one correlator setup per band. In Band 6, the correlator will be configured with four contiguous spectral windows having 937.5 MHz bandwidth and 488.281 kHz (0.605 km/s) channel spacing, providing maximum spectral coverage at resolution appropriate for typical linewidths in these sources (5 km/s). In Band 9, we configure the correlator with four contiguous spectral windows having 1875 MHz bandwidth and 481.287 kHz (0.221 km/s) channel spacing.
Sensitivity Requirements: The spectral simulations described above indicate that lines from all molecular targets should be >1 K in intensity. A lower rms level may be required for those molecules not detected in the single-dish observations (i.e. those with beam-diluted compact emission). Integration times were determined using the finest resolution bandwidth to an rms level of 500 mK. The ALMA OT for Cycle-2 estimates a total observing time of 6.3 hours.
Array Setup: The combined CSO and HIFI results indicate that most of the emission in these sources is arising from warmer, compact (<3'') regions, in agreement with the CARMA Orion-KL observations. Therefore, the best angular resolution is in the range of 0.5'' - 1'', which allows us to probe the compact source structure expected at higher excitation levels without completely resolving out the more extended 1'' - 5'' emission. In Band 6, the C32-3 configuration (ang. res. 0.6'', max. ang.scale 7.6'') is ideal for these observations. In Band 9, the C32-1 configuration (ang. res. 0.55'', max. ang. scale 3.6'') is best. It is expected that the higher frequency observations will probe highly compact gas. However, there is a chance that the Band 9 observations could resolve out part of the extended emission in these sources; comparisons will be made to the single-dish spectra and follow-up ACA observations can be conducted in future observing cycles.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose ALMA observations of a set of molecule-rich star-forming regions to probe the influence of physical environment on molecular complexity. The overall science goal of this program is to observe a statistically-significant sample of sources, cover a range of physical environments, target selected frequency windows containing transitions from several known complex interstellar organic molecules, and probe a range of excitation energies for each molecule. The results of these observations can be used to correlate the relative abundances of organic molecules with the physical properties of the source (i.e. temperature, density, age, dynamics, etc.). The ultimate goal is to determine which molecules can be used as clocks of the star-formation process. These proposed observations serve as the next phase in our ongoing observational program to conduct deep spectral line surveys at 230 GHz, 670 GHz, and 1.16 THz using the Caltech Submillimeter Observatory (CSO) and the HIFI instrument on the Herschel Space Observatory.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2011.0.00314.S: Unraveling the Mysteries of Complex Interstellar Organic Chemistry Using Spectral Line Surveys; Susanna Widicus Weaver 2012.1.00212.S: Deciphering Complex Chemistry in Star-Forming Regions with Complex Source Morphologies; Susanna Widicus Weaver

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Submillimeter Astrophysics Group, California Institute of Technology
Department of Physics, Ohio State University
